componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll hear first from John Kreger with William Blair.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, can you just elaborate a bit on your decision to alter the Sirona relationship? And how should we think about the sort of puts and takes to your business over the next 12 months?
componenttext: Scott, can you just elaborate a bit on your decision to alter the Sirona relationship? And how should we think about the sort of puts and takes to your business over the next 12 months?

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, John. I'll talk first about strategy. So I think that's very important. And then I'll turn it over to Ann to maybe talk some of the economics. But I think it's critical that as I talk about our decision, we also talk about the history and pa
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, John. I'll talk first about strategy. So I think that's very important. And then I'll turn it over to Ann to maybe talk some of the economics. But I think it's critical that as I talk about our decision, we also talk about the history and partnership because we do have people who are newer to the story, and I think it gives very important context. If you go back to the 1990s, it really was a vision towards the future that the Patterson management team had as they approached Siemens Dental with the offer that we would sell and service the CEREC 2 exclusively. At the time, Siemens had a game-changing idea with single-visit chairside dentistry but really had very limited commercial success to sell the product. We like to say that agreement was the beginning of what we call a 20-year overnight success story, as we partnered with the eventual spin-out of Siemens Dental, which we -- became Sirona, to really do true pioneer work to change dentistry. And I would say we could not be more proud, and I speak for all of the employees of Patterson, about the work we've done together. Now more -- or more excited about what we are going to accomplish together in the future. I think it's important that everyone knows our executive teams, both at Patterson and Sirona for years, have been very consistent in our approach that there would be a day where Patterson will need to expand the portfolio of products we sell to meet the needs of our customers, and also Sirona will want to access more of the market through potential expanded distribution. This is the critical point. I think we both, as partners, feel now is the perfect time at the end of our contract to move our relationship to the next level. And really, this is predicated on our mutual confidence, and I would say, strong confidence in our ability to compete in the marketplace. As a reminder, we've seen this scenario. We've -- it's playing out right now in our chair business. And our great partner, A-dec, we remain their largest partner. We have the ability to sell more product, which has helped us access more customers. So the other piece is really unlocking growth for both companies and the commitment of both companies of helping the profession accelerate the adoption of digital dentistry. So a key part of this strategic decision is we both feel an increased interest in activity that will come from expanded distribution will lead to a potential acceleration of sales. Bottom line is more people are going to be talking about digital dentistry. More people will be talking about CEREC. And we think we can sell 7 out of 10 instead of 5 out of 5. And over time, net-net, this will be a real positive for Patterson and Sirona.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So John, as it relates to your question around guidance. So as we think about our updated guidance for 2017, it does anticipate some headwinds regarding Sirona. Specifically, we anticipate there could be some near-term distractions with our field sales fo
componenttext: So John, as it relates to your question around guidance. So as we think about our updated guidance for 2017, it does anticipate some headwinds regarding Sirona. Specifically, we anticipate there could be some near-term distractions with our field sales force around the Sirona announcement. And then in addition to that, we anticipate we'll incur some incremental cost to protect the technology assets we've built over the last 20 years. When you think longer term out to 2018, at this point, there's still a lot of moving pieces. In addition to Sirona, we plan to add additional technology products to the portfolio. We're onboarding large new customers. And then, of course, we should start to benefit from our ERP investment in the back half of 2018. So we'll continue to work through the challenges that we're facing over the next 90 days. And our plan is to update you on our longer-term outlook next quarter. But I would just emphasize that longer term, we do believe that the underlying business organically will be able to grow and continue generating significant amounts of cash.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And maybe just one more quick one to clarify. That -- your comments on Animal Health around the pharma manufacturer pricing environment. Were you referring to just maybe a more muted kind of inflationary trend on their part? Or is this more a chang
componenttext: Great. And maybe just one more quick one to clarify. That -- your comments on Animal Health around the pharma manufacturer pricing environment. Were you referring to just maybe a more muted kind of inflationary trend on their part? Or is this more a change in the terms that you can buy those products from them?

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Great question, John. And I think we really want to look at it from 3 points. So I'll sort of talk about the current business challenges, give you full context and have Ann get into the financial impact and then talk about our mitigation go-forward p
componenttext: Yes. Great question, John. And I think we really want to look at it from 3 points. So I'll sort of talk about the current business challenges, give you full context and have Ann get into the financial impact and then talk about our mitigation go-forward plan. Really, what we're experienced right now is I would classify as sort of a near-term disruption as a result of some manufacturer consolidation in the space that, as we've talked about, is putting pressure on our margins. And I don't want to call out specific manufacturers, but it's clear that we are in the midst of a significant realignment of some of our key partners. With that said, we really think long term. And I think the important thing is that we have repeatedly demonstrated our ability to move share in the market. And that with our scale reaching both companion and production animal customers really gives us confidence that we'll be the partner of choice among manufacturers as consolidation settles in. So I'll turn it over to Ann to talk -- walk you through the financial impact, and then I want to talk about mitigation.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So while we saw a nice top line growth in the second quarter, about 10% in the U.S., our operating profit decreased double digits, about 18% on an adjusted basis. And I would just say that the 80 basis point decline that you saw, the challenges that
componenttext: Sure. So while we saw a nice top line growth in the second quarter, about 10% in the U.S., our operating profit decreased double digits, about 18% on an adjusted basis. And I would just say that the 80 basis point decline that you saw, the challenges that we're seeing with the branded pharmaceutical manufacturers, account for 100% of that decline. And it's a variety of factors, John. Whether it's rebates, mix, and just kind of overall, the changes that we're seeing in the terms of the agreements. Where we are implementing programs immediately to respond to these challenges, but it will take some time to work through. And as a result, we're taking down guidance for the back half the year to more closely align with our current quarter performance. So while we're initially targeting operating margins for the segment to be flat for the year after absorbing and allocation for the step up in expense associated with the ERP implementation, we now expect margins for the full year to decline between 40 and 60 basis points for the year in Animal Health.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I'll just finish by saying our Animal Health management team is, obviously, actively engaged with our key partners, as well as myself. And it's clear that our growing sales momentum across the platform, that Patterson Animal Health is the growing part
componenttext: And I'll just finish by saying our Animal Health management team is, obviously, actively engaged with our key partners, as well as myself. And it's clear that our growing sales momentum across the platform, that Patterson Animal Health is the growing partner of choice for many end customers. And we will continue to drive that value and look forward to deepening manufacturer partnerships to serve the market. And this is an issue that we intend to get results over the next 6 months.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Roberto Fatta with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Roberto Fatta with Evercore ISI.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of the Sirona relationship, obviously, over a long period, it's been very successful. But there's also been pressures on the sales force when you have a minimum levels, and you need to hit certain targets relevant to a certain product. Can you ta
componenttext: In terms of the Sirona relationship, obviously, over a long period, it's been very successful. But there's also been pressures on the sales force when you have a minimum levels, and you need to hit certain targets relevant to a certain product. Can you talk a bit about may be use the chair example of what you've learned. But talk a bit about sort of post the expiration of this exclusivity, what do you think it'll do to kind of -- the sales force and how do you expect them to react and whether or not this could actually be sort of a rallying event for folks versus maybe something that leads to, I don't know, departures or more transitionary challenges?

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ross, great question. And I would say, we've had a very thorough communication plan. And we had over 100 of our general managers in Minneapolis last week walking through the strategy of what we're doing and why now is the right time. And I would tell you,
componenttext: Ross, great question. And I would say, we've had a very thorough communication plan. And we had over 100 of our general managers in Minneapolis last week walking through the strategy of what we're doing and why now is the right time. And I would tell you, there is the sense of a rallying cry both for and I think I want to be clear, for both the support of Sirona and our long-term prospects, but also, we talked about one Patterson. And we have some tenets around one Patterson, and one of those is customers first. And really the feedback I've gotten, and we've done some focus groups as well with some of our top salespeople, is the ability to at every point with a customer first in the decision-making process is incredibly powerful. And I think the exclusivity, particularly on CEREC, serve Patterson and Sirona so well historically. Because you need focus and commitment to make a market. And we made a market together. But we feel now there's momentum and actually a real chance for acceleration in the space that's going to let both Patterson and Sirona win. So we learn this through the A-dec decision, which has been very powerful. And I talked to our salespeople all over the country. And I can't tell you how many times our best salespeople say, let me compete. Just give me all the products and we'll do what's best for the customer. And then that also puts, I think, a really excited competitive spirit back on the manufacturer that best product wins the most effective, most efficient product wins. So in my previous answer, I talked about the confidence that Sirona and Patterson share, and I have been in this relationship for 20 years. We make this decision together as partners because of our confidence to compete and our confidence that this is right for customers.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And yes, was it possible that, that is helpful to you in sort of gaining share on the DSOs? so I think their choice and their best price center would be a preference versus having just one product to push in on the CAD/CAM side.
componenttext: And yes, was it possible that, that is helpful to you in sort of gaining share on the DSOs? so I think their choice and their best price center would be a preference versus having just one product to push in on the CAD/CAM side.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, obviously, and I think it played into our discussions with Heartland. When you look at those large customers, they want access to all products. And then they really truly want a logistics partner, service partner to take care of everything. So while
componenttext: Yes, obviously, and I think it played into our discussions with Heartland. When you look at those large customers, they want access to all products. And then they really truly want a logistics partner, service partner to take care of everything. So while we have opened a very large door in Heartland, I think -- and I've had multiple conversations with many customers and are very actively helping our dental group as we expand and expect to win sales over time that this absolutely plays to the strategy. I think it also creates plenty of opportunity for Sirona over time to strengthen their story in the DSO community as well.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016

componenttext: That sits well with what Patterson does well in terms of our competitive advantage around service, around software, around technology. As Scott said, Heartland is all about the customer. It was great. I think it's going to be a win-win partnership. And I think the other thing that's super exciting for me is that the investments that we'll partner with Heartland on will help us to really build a platform that we'll be able to leverage as we bring additional DSOs online. So definitely the work we're doing together will benefit the entire DSO space.

componenttext: Yes. And I would say there's going to be follow-on benefits in terms of the e-commerce initiatives that are going to benefit all of our customers.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one quick financial question. You mentioned how you have flexibility on the buyback given the outstanding authorization. Are there any limitations you have related to leverage? Or I guess, any gating factors in terms of being able to act on the b
componenttext: And just one quick financial question. You mentioned how you have flexibility on the buyback given the outstanding authorization. Are there any limitations you have related to leverage? Or I guess, any gating factors in terms of being able to act on the buyback?

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. So I think just to kind of walk through what we've said so far and then I'll get specifically to your leverage question. But we spent $50 million on share repurchases to the first half of the year, which is a little over 1 million shares. And as you k
componenttext: No. So I think just to kind of walk through what we've said so far and then I'll get specifically to your leverage question. But we spent $50 million on share repurchases to the first half of the year, which is a little over 1 million shares. And as you know, we're committed to driving shareholder value and cash generation is a real asset. So we'll continue to increase the dividend and view value-enhancing share repurchases. We've previously communicated as part of our overall capital allocation strategy that we'll allocate between $100 million to $150 million of free cash flow annually with share repurchases. But depending on market conditions, we make choose to accelerate the buyback further. And given our financial strength, we certainly have the ability to step up our share repurchases if we chose to do so. Our current leverage is at about 2.5x or 2.6x EBITDA, so definitely have room there if we chose to do so.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll now hear from Jeff Johnson with Robert Baird.
componenttext: And we'll now hear from Jeff Johnson with Robert Baird.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Ann, maybe a couple of follow-ups I'll start with you if I could. You mentioned in one of your answers that some of the disruption here maybe protecting the technology assets you've built around the CEREC platform and the Sirona platform. I guess, I'm
componenttext: So Ann, maybe a couple of follow-ups I'll start with you if I could. You mentioned in one of your answers that some of the disruption here maybe protecting the technology assets you've built around the CEREC platform and the Sirona platform. I guess, I'm not quite sure what you mean there if you could maybe clarify that. And then also wondering on the sales disruption side for CEREC if that is indeed an issue you're kind of imputing in guidance. Why would there be a sales disruption in the near term? I would think reps who want to be out there selling this, especially for and I heard you put in the quota in now in this morning for the next 9 months or so before the change happens. So why the top line impact? I'm a little unclear on that as well.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll start and I think Scott will probably follow up with a few comments. But I think as it relates to protecting the assets that we've built this is really around a couple of the areas. One is our people. We've been selling this product for 20-plus
componenttext: Sure. I'll start and I think Scott will probably follow up with a few comments. But I think as it relates to protecting the assets that we've built this is really around a couple of the areas. One is our people. We've been selling this product for 20-plus years. We have deep expertise. So just making sure that we're doing the right thing for our people in terms of as we transition to a competitive environment. And then it's really the intellectual property around the processes that we've built around training and after-sales work. We have quite the asset of the Patterson Technology Center in terms of providing first-class support, and we just want to make sure that we're doing the right thing. And so there'll be some additional investment there to make sure that we protect that IP. As it relates a sales disruption. I think when we put the guidance together, we wanted to make sure that we were conservative. And as we've gone through other transitions in the past historically, whether that's the A-dec change or the change when we changed how we sold other technology products with the software days. Sometimes if you're going to a transition, there is some of your terms, disruption in the yield. So from a conservative standpoint, we did use the top line and our outlook just to account for that. But with that said, we fully intend to execute on the contract for the balance of our exclusivity. And we've leave no rock unturned in terms of sales leads. But I'll leave it up to Scott to add to that.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, ant. And thanks, Jeff. That's a great question. And I just want to reiterate what Ann said. Number one, he's taken the conservative approach, which we have as we put together guidance for the back half of the year. Two, it's an absolute commi
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, ant. And thanks, Jeff. That's a great question. And I just want to reiterate what Ann said. Number one, he's taken the conservative approach, which we have as we put together guidance for the back half of the year. Two, it's an absolute commitment to defend what we've built. And we will do that at every turn because we feel it's an absolute competitive advantage today, and it's only going to grow with time. Now 3, to the sales force. And I would say, I have great confidence in our managers, in our salespeople, that absolutely, as you said, use this as their rallying product. We have incredibly deep relationships with Sirona. It's family. to Patterson and family to Sirona and it is our intent that we use this as an opportunity to finish off the chapter of the 20-year exclusive. But also this as a launching pad for what we think was going to be a very exciting time competition. And when I had our people in Minneapolis last week, what got me the most energized is the confidence of our managers and how excited they are to compete and leverage what we -- but blood, sweat and tears that we put over the last 20 years. I think you're right in terms of the conservatism in the guidance, but it is our absolute intent that we exceed those conservative targets.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then I guess, my last question would just be Scott, is there any way you can just bucket of guidance was being cut at $0.35 on the year. Obviously, some has soft end markets. It doesn't sound like the ERP spending is changing. So may b
componenttext: That's helpful. And then I guess, my last question would just be Scott, is there any way you can just bucket of guidance was being cut at $0.35 on the year. Obviously, some has soft end markets. It doesn't sound like the ERP spending is changing. So may be how do we bucket the $0.35 between sales force reduction when the cut this past June, the Sirona stuff maybe currency and some other factors. Can you help us there at all?

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. So if we think about what's changed in the marketplace and how those recent events are impacting our second quarter results and then the implications to 2017. You touched on 2 factors with unexpected changes in the marketplace that negati
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. So if we think about what's changed in the marketplace and how those recent events are impacting our second quarter results and then the implications to 2017. You touched on 2 factors with unexpected changes in the marketplace that negatively impacts the balance of the year. So there is a softness in the U.S. dental market and then challenges with branded pharmaceutical pricing in our Animal Health business. And then in addition to those factors, it's a strategic decisions we made in the first half of the year most recently the move towards nonexclusive manufacturing relationships within our technology portfolio. So when I think about breaking that down, what I can tell you is about half of the reduction in guidance is due to Animal Health, and the other half is due to Dental. And when I think about Dental, Jeff, I would say probably 1/2 to 2/3 is really more on the consumer market softening and some disruption from the sales force restructuring. And the other 1/3 is probably around the Sirona piece, that's rough buckets.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Jon Block with Stifel, please go ahead.
componenttext: And Jon Block with Stifel, please go ahead.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a start, and I'll keep it to two [ph]. North American consumable growth was -- I think the weakest was around the recession. And you mentioned marketing and sales force I believe mostly sales force. So maybe just curious and with all due respec
componenttext: Maybe just a start, and I'll keep it to two [ph]. North American consumable growth was -- I think the weakest was around the recession. And you mentioned marketing and sales force I believe mostly sales force. So maybe just curious and with all due respect my view see this as a potential outcome from the sales pruning? I mean, obviously, one of your main assets is the rep relationship with the. So now several months later, post some of the changes, what took you by surprise on the rep front?

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, talk about the general market, John. And then I'll talk about the rep piece. I think they're 2 important parts. I would say on the general market commentary that the soft less -- the softness we experienced in the entire industry experienced in the s
componenttext: Yes, talk about the general market, John. And then I'll talk about the rep piece. I think they're 2 important parts. I would say on the general market commentary that the soft less -- the softness we experienced in the entire industry experienced in the summer, continued through the fall. And as we look at the back half of the year, we decided to take a conservative approach thing that there wouldn't be any market improvement. I would say the market is stable. And if I had to look at a growth rate, I would say it's probably 0 to 100 basis points. So a lethargic market. So while we're disappointed that it didn't swing back posts summer, I think we have really strong potential fundamentals for the market that give us optimism going forward. You've heard this it's stable to improving consumer confidence. It's low unemployment levels. It's continued trend of customers investing in the technology. And then it's the demand driven for favorable North American demographics. So on the sales force side, and I think this is an important part of the strategy because we absolutely are committed to it and feel like we made the right move to move the business towards where the market is going. The sales erosion is contained to a certain number of customers. But when you look at the upside opportunity of almost 19,000 new customers that we've assigned some of our best salespeople to, we look at the long-term growth opportunity as being substantial and material. What we did not anticipate in the front end, and maybe I'll turn it over to Ann to talk about just what consumer softening to our operating model.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So great question, Jonathan. So certainly when we put together our guidance for the year, knowing that we were going to do the rep realignment, we absolutely factored in some distractions in field. I think what we didn't account for is the continued
componenttext: Yes. So great question, Jonathan. So certainly when we put together our guidance for the year, knowing that we were going to do the rep realignment, we absolutely factored in some distractions in field. I think what we didn't account for is the continued and softening off the market or end market softening. And when we look across the industry by my estimate, we're off by about 200 basis points from the trailing 12 months. And it's really that factor that's causing the reduction in guidance. When you go back to my script, what we're trying to stay there when we were talking about the rep restructuring, accounting for most of the decline is that if you added the rep restructuring back and factor that in, we'd be growing with the market.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I would just add one last piece. If you look at the strength of our equipment business in the quarter and that is what the realign sales force. I think that shows that the productivity of our salespeople and the sales we're making across the plat
componenttext: Yes. And I would just add one last piece. If you look at the strength of our equipment business in the quarter and that is what the realign sales force. I think that shows that the productivity of our salespeople and the sales we're making across the platform we haven't missed the beat on that side. Maybe Ann has one other comment she could throw in.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the other thing that you look at the rep realignment just to make the very salient point that the upside from these actions is much greater than the current business loss. So when we look longer term, we absolutely believe this is the right m
componenttext: Yes. I think the other thing that you look at the rep realignment just to make the very salient point that the upside from these actions is much greater than the current business loss. So when we look longer term, we absolutely believe this is the right move in terms of unlocking market potential for our best reps.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016

componenttext: That's very helpful. Just one other one on the side of the business on the vet side. Can you give more clarity on the issue with the branded manufacturers? I apologize if I missed the details. But the industry has been consolidating for some time now. So I guess what is incremental or new with the marketplace that's resulting in this pressure? And then just from a margin perspective, is it anything you can do to alleviate the margin pressures from the manufacturers. Are you just trying to find other sources of savings to help you guys with profitability?

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start. It's two things, John. And as I said in my prior comment, I don't want to get into the specifics of key manufacturers and negotiate in public. But there are some significant realignments going on right now. We're working through that. The mark
componenttext: I'll start. It's two things, John. And as I said in my prior comment, I don't want to get into the specifics of key manufacturers and negotiate in public. But there are some significant realignments going on right now. We're working through that. The market is already also that's happening in distribution. And that's why we are very confident that we will move through this and capture the value that we bring for the customers that. And I maybe have Ann some color to that.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think to answer your question. Is there opportunity with manufacturers? And then internally, I think the answer to that is bold[ph]. So when I think about the size and scale of our organization with the combination of production animal and companio
componenttext: Yes. I think to answer your question. Is there opportunity with manufacturers? And then internally, I think the answer to that is bold[ph]. So when I think about the size and scale of our organization with the combination of production animal and companion animal and really serving both those markets in the value that we bring to the manufacturer community, I really think that that's the consolidation settled down, we will be the partner of choice. But I think that's a little bit longer term. When I think about what we can do in the shorter term, while we're lowering guidance, we are promptly taking steps to address the headwinds that we've identified. There are many levers we can pull to offset some of them pressure. For example, we've identified additional and we have ongoing cost management initiatives underway to bring savings to the company. But of course, it's a balance, right? Because we also have the incremental step-up and the expense from our IT investment. And of course, we're just ramping out that implementation. So it's definitely a balance. We also are continuing to work on our integration activities and pushing cars to drive incremental synergies. So we are all over this, but it will take some time to work through.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And ladies and gentlemen, we have time for one more question. We'll go to Robert Jones from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And ladies and gentlemen, we have time for one more question. We'll go to Robert Jones from Goldman Sachs.

componenttext: This is Nathan Rich on for Bob this morning. Regional I just wanted to go back to your consumables market. And if you could clarify how consumables trended during the quarter. I think the comments that you guys have made on your last call about August [ph] seem to be that consumables were moving more in the right direction. So just curious how trends played out in September and October? And then some other things you called out whether had the potential had out in October. so just curious if you saw that as well.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nathan, this is Scott. I'll take that first, and Ann can give some color in the end. I think it's very important when we're talking about volatility in consumables, we're talking about a very small band. This is a stable market that's moving between 2% un
componenttext: Nathan, this is Scott. I'll take that first, and Ann can give some color in the end. I think it's very important when we're talking about volatility in consumables, we're talking about a very small band. This is a stable market that's moving between 2% underlying market growth and maybe flattish underlying market growth. So we don't want to overreact to the trends. I would say, we saw a little pickup coming into the fall, but then it settled back down. So what we see is just the stable market. We have a lot of confidence that the market is not receiving from where it's at right now. Obviously, a lot happened here this fall politically. And it'll be interesting how small businesses, potentially, could see some positive influence from Washington going forward, which would benefit the dental market. But I think I just want to caution everyone that these are very small bands of volatility, and maybe turn it over to Ann.

headline: Patterson Companies, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2016

componenttext: Yes. So when I think back to first quarter, we didn't want to overreact for the consumable results. But of course, we had a lot of noise going on with our restructuring activities. You're right. We did see some rebound in October. But unfortunately, the softness has continued with similar results in Q2. I think as we look at our Q2, our Q2 actually improved throughout the quarter. And I think that really speaks more to the sales rep realignment settled down and begin to clawback our customers that we lost and win back that share. So I think for us we thought -- and again, as Scott said, it's a narrow band. But we did see some improvement in October.
